summary: The awaitWithTimeout workflow utility does not immediately resume when the condition becomes true; instead, it waits for the full timeout duration to elapse before checking again. This causes workflows to hang until the timeout expires rather than responding promptly to signal-triggered state changes.
userImpact: Workflows receiving signals do not resume execution immediately, causing unexpected delays in workflow completion and making signal-based control flow unreliable.
rootCause: The awaitWithTimeout implementation does not interrupt the timeout when the awaited condition becomes true; it only checks the condition after the timeout expires.
resolutionDetails: Issue was fixed by modifying awaitWithTimeout to interrupt the timeout when the condition evaluates to true rather than waiting for the full duration.
keyQuote: Run the workflow, send `cancel` signal, workflow stays running. Only after timeout (600 seconds) it completes with result `CANCEL`.
